abstract.text: A credential that results from a successful Apple ID authentication.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

abstract.text: Make it easy for users to log into apps and services.
A credential that results from a successful Apple ID authentication.
A token that the app uses to interact with the server.
The contact information the user authorized your app to access.
The user’s email address.
The user’s full name from their Apple ID or a user-submitted value provided from the Sign in with Apple UI.
A JSON Web Token (JWT) that securely communicates information about the user to the app.
A value that indicates whether the user appears to be a real person.
An arbitrary string that your app provides to the request that generates the credential.
An identifier for the authenticated user.
A mechanism for generating requests to authenticate users based on their Apple ID.
An interface that all credentials share.
Possible values for the real user indicator.
The view that creates the Sign in with Apple button for display.
Provide a way for users of your app to set up an account and start using your services.

doc://com.apple.authenticationservices/d.title: Implementing User Authentication with Sign in with Apple

abstract.text: Build a fluid sign-in experience for your tvOS apps using AuthenticationServices.

doc://com.apple.authenticationservices/d.title: Simplifying User Authentication in a tvOS App

abstract.text: An entitlement that lets your app use Sign in with Apple.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
